# Contributing to Skills4SocialScience

Thank you for your interest in contributing to Skills4SocialScience! This document provides guidelines for contributing to this repository.

## Code of Conduct

By participating in this project, you agree to maintain a respectful and inclusive environment for all contributors.

## How to Contribute

### Reporting Bugs

1. Check if the bug has already been reported in [Issues](https://github.com/yourusername/Skills4SocialScience/issues)
2. If not, create a new issue using the Bug Report template
3. Provide detailed information about the bug and steps to reproduce it

### Suggesting Features

1. Check if the feature has already been suggested in [Issues](https://github.com/yourusername/Skills4SocialScience/issues)
2. If not, create a new issue using the Feature Request template
3. Clearly describe the use case and proposed solution

### Submitting Skills

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a new branch for your skill (`git checkout -b skill/your-skill-name`)
3. Add your skill to the appropriate category folder
4. Follow the [Skill Development Guide](../docs/skill-development.md)
5. Test your skill thoroughly
6. Submit a pull request with a clear description

## Skill Submission Checklist

Before submitting a skill, ensure:

- [ ] The skill is placed in the correct category folder
- [ ] A comprehensive README.md is included
- [ ] Installation instructions are clear and complete
- [ ] Usage examples are provided
- [ ] The skill has been tested in multiple environments
- [ ] All dependencies are documented
- [ ] The skill follows academic integrity standards
- [ ] The code is well-commented
- [ ] The license is compatible with MIT

## Pull Request Process

1. Update the main README.md to include your skill in the appropriate category
2. Ensure all tests pass
3. Update documentation as needed
4. Request review from maintainers
5. Address any feedback promptly

## Development Guidelines

### File Structure

```
skills/
├── 1-literature-review/
│   └── your-skill/
│       ├── README.md
│       ├── skill.json (or skill configuration)
│       └── examples/
├── 2-research-design/
├── 3-data-collection/
├── 4-data-analysis/
├── 5-writing-publishing/
├── 6-presentation/
└── 7-teaching/
```

### Documentation Standards

- Use clear, concise language
- Provide both English and Chinese documentation when possible
- Include practical examples
- Document all prerequisites and dependencies
- Explain the research context and use cases

### Code Quality

- Write clean, readable code
- Include comments for complex logic
- Follow existing code style in the repository
- Avoid introducing breaking changes
- Test thoroughly before submission

## Community Guidelines

- Be respectful and constructive in all interactions
- Help newcomers get started
- Share your research experiences and use cases
- Provide helpful feedback on pull requests
- Report issues clearly and completely

## Questions?

If you have questions about contributing, please:
- Check the [FAQ](../docs/faq.md)
- Open a discussion in [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/yourusername/Skills4SocialScience/discussions)
- Contact the maintainers

Thank you for contributing to the social science research community!
